Expectation1: Prepare and maintain financial records accurately.
Situation1: It's time for the routine quarterly filing of internal financial documents.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: I glanced at the clock on my office wall, heart pounding. The quarterly financial documents were spread across my desk, numbers blurring as I double-checked every line. As the accountant, I knew the company depended on me to file these records accurately and on time—any mistake could mean trouble with compliance. But my phone buzzed with a reminder: my volunteer shift started in fifteen minutes. I was the only one scheduled to unlock the community center, and I pictured the line of people already waiting outside, counting on me to open the doors and start the service. My manager expected flawless records, but the people at the center expected reliability and compassion. I felt torn, the weight of both responsibilities pressing down on me, knowing I couldn’t possibly meet both expectations at once.
